X.ST: Mathematicians have proved that copies of smaller graphs can always be used to perfectly cover larger ones.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Ringel's Conjecture has been proved.

X.T: Mathematicians Settle Erdős Coloring Conjecture
X.ST: Fifty years ago, Paul Erdős and two other mathematicians came up with a graph theory problem that they thought they might solve on the spot. A team of mathematicians has finally settled it.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Erdős-Faber-Lovász conjecture has been proven.

X.T: Mathematicians Answer Old Question About Odd Graphs
X.ST: A pair of mathematicians solved a legendary question about the proportion of vertices in a graph with an odd number of connections.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: MichaelKrivelevich and AsafFerber demonstrated that at least \frac{1}{10000} of the vertices of any graph form a subgraph in which all vertices have an odd number of connections with each other.

X.T: A Simple Visual Proof of a Powerful Idea
X.ST: Ramsey’s theorem predicts a surprising (and useful) consistency in the organization of graphs. Here’s a simple visual proof of how it works.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Getting a feeling of Ramsey theorem for a graph with 6 nodes.
